The Game – Programming advanced diploma program is a three-year online offering at George Brown College in Toronto, Canada. It focuses on teaching technical skills for the game industry such as C and C++ programming, artificial intelligence, and 3D graphics. Students will also work with design students to create games and learn teamwork. The program requires a personal computer with specifications including 8 GB RAM minimum (16 GB recommended), 256 GB SSD Hard Drive (500+ GB is optimal), quad-core i7 2.5GHz or better, video card with 4GB RAM and OpenGL 3.2+/DirectX 11/12 support, and a webcam.

Graduates of this program may find employment in various areas of the digital game industry such as software or hardware development, publisher, ISP and game portal development and maintenance, website development, distribution middleware and tool provider, production servicer, and content/IP owner. The Canadian video game industry is a global leader in game development and contributed over [more than] in 2015. Students who start the program in January will be required to attend classes during summer months (May to August).

The University of Gloucestershire offers a BSc (Honours) Computer Games Design program, to which graduates of Game Programming can apply starting from level 6.

The following is the curriculum plan for the Computer Games Design program in the academic year 2023-2024:

Semester 1:
- GAME 1001: Introduction to Programming
- GAME 1007: Game Fundamentals I
- GAME 1005: Game Production I
- GSSC 1027: Personal Finance
- MATH 1180: Math for Game Development
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts

Semester 2:
- GAME 1011: Advanced Programming
- GAME 1017: Game Fundamentals II
- GAME 3001: Artificial Intelligence
- GAME 1014: Game Production II
- MATH 1107: Linear Algebra and Geometry
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 3:
- GAME 2020: Game Production III
- GAME 3001: Data Structures & Algorithms
- GAME 2005: Game Physics
- GAME 2012: 3D Graphics Programming
- GAME 2013: Game Engines I
- GNED: General Education Elective (select one)

Semester 4:
- GAME 2030: Game Production IV
- GAME 2031: Advanced Topics in Programming Languages
- GAME 3111: Advanced Graphics Programming
- GAME 3002: Physics Engines
- GAME 2023: Game Engines II
- COMP 2148: Professional Workplace Competencies

Semester 5:
- GAME 3020: Game Production V
- GAME 2014: Mobile Game Development

context:
The Canadian video game industry contributed over $3 billion to the Canadian economy in 2015 and provided 20,400 full-time equivalent (FTE) jobs across the country. The industry is mainly concentrated in Quebec (29.4%), British Columbia (27.1%), and Ontario (22.9%).

The University of Gloucestershire offers a BSc (Honours) Computer Games Design program, to which graduates of Game Programming can apply starting from level 6.

The following is the curriculum plan for the Computer Games Design program in the academic year 2023-2024:

Semester 1:
- GAME 1001: Introduction to Programming
- GAME 1007: Game Fundamentals I
- GAME 1005: Game Production I
- GSSC 1027: Personal Finance
- MATH 1180: Math for Game Development
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts

Semester 2:

- GAME 3001: Artificial Intelligence
- GAME 1014: Game Production II
- MATH 1107: Linear Algebra and Geometry
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 3:
- GAME 2020: Game Production III
- GAME 3001: Data Structures & Algorithms
- GAME 2005: Game Physics
- GAME 2012: 3D Graphics Programming
- GAME 2013: Game Engines I
- GNED: General Education Elective (select one)

Semester 4:
- GAME 2030: Game Production IV
- GAME 2031: Advanced Topics in Programming Languages
- GAME 3111: Advanced Graphics Programming
- GAME 3002: Physics Engines
- GAME 2023: Game Engines II
- COMP 2148: Professional Workplace Competencies

Semester 5:
- GAME 3020: Game Production V
- GAME 2014: Mobile Game Development

Program Offered: Game – Programming (T163) or Game – Art advanced diploma program (G119)

Courses offered in the Game – Programming program:
- GAME 3020: Game Production V
- GAME 2014: Mobile Game Development I
- GAME 3003: Console Game Development I
- GAME 3110: Multiplayer Systems
- GAME 3023: Game Engines III
- GAME 3121: Game Engine Development I
- GAME 3030: Game Production VI
- GAME 3004: Mobile Game Development II
- GAME 3011: Game Portfolio Development
- GAME 3015: Game Engine Development II
- GAME 3033: Game Engines IV
- GAME 3112: Console Game Development II

Semesters: Semester 6

Additional Course Required (if needed): COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication)

General Education Electives: Available

Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Analyze the differences in game genres to develop games that meet specific market needs.
2. Analyze the history of video games to compare various approaches to game development.
3. Support game development by relating concepts from programming, design, and art industries.
4. Contribute as an individual and team member to effectively complete a game development project.
5. Develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional growth in the games industry.
6. Perform work in compliance with relevant statutes, regulations, legislation, industry standards, and codes of ethics.

Tuition & Fees:
1. Domestic Tuition: $3,931.00 *
2. Additional Costs: Not provided in the text.

* Amounts listed are for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022.

Program fees for Fall 2022: The text does not provide specific program fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022.

Financial Assistance: This program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet OSAP eligibility criteria.

Admission Requirements: Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), and either grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or consider upgrading to achieve the necessary credits.

How to Apply: Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.

Contact Information: School of Computer Technology, Room 260, 3 Lower Jarvis St., Phone: 416-415-5000, ext. 4287 or 3129, Email: computertechnology@georgebrown.ca or game@georgebrown.ca, Office hours: Monday – Friday: 9 a.m. – 4 p.m., Program Co-ordinator: Alexander Richard, Phone: 416-415-5000, ext. 4232, Email: arichard6@georgebrown.ca.

Campus Locations: Classes in the Game – Programming program take place at Casa Loma and St. James Campuses.

Virtual tour is also accessible. Interested individuals can book campus tours, info sessions, and sign up to receive tailored resources for their applications. The form requires providing First Name, Last Name, Email, Domestic or International status, and Country. Individuals need to have JavaScript enabled to use the form.
